tree.name: First slide

children.name: Reductions
Intuitive idea behind “problem A is NP hard”
keywords: Intuitive idea behind “problem A is NP hard”

children.name: { m#w#t :
keywords: { m#w#t :

children.name: Suppose that you could solve problem A in polynomial time.
keywords: Suppose that you could solve problem A in polynomial time.

children.name: Then every problem B ∈ NP can also be solved in polynomial time
keywords: Then every problem B ∈ NP can also be solved in polynomial time

children.name: There is a reduction from B to A, which preserves polynomial time.
keywords: There is a reduction from B to A, which preserves polynomial time.

children.name: this can mean several things
keywords: this can mean several things

children.name: Turing reductions
Deterministic polynomial time Turing reduction
keywords: Deterministic polynomial time Turing reduction

children.name: Idea. Problem B can be solved by a deterministic polynomial time Turing machine, which is allowed to ask oracle queries to problem A.
keywords: Idea. Problem B can be solved by a deterministic polynomial time Turing machine, which is allowed to ask oracle queries to problem A.

children.name: Machines with oracles
Machines with oracles
keywords: Machines with oracles

children.name: A Turing machine with oracle A ⊆ Γ* is defined as follows.
keywords: A Turing machine with oracle A ⊆ Γ* is defined as follows.

children.name: maybe deterministic or nondeterministic
keywords: maybe deterministic or nondeterministic

children.name: The machine has two tapes, input tape and oracle tape. Initially, the input tape contains the input word and the oracle tape is empty.
keywords: The machine has two tapes, input tape and oracle tape. Initially, the input tape contains the input word and the oracle tape is empty.

children.name: The machine can execute an oracle query (in unit time). If the word on the oracle tape belongs to A, then the oracle tape is replaced by “yes”, otherwise the second tape is replaced by “no”.
keywords: The machine can execute an oracle query (in unit time). If the word on the oracle tape belongs to A, then the oracle tape is replaced by “yes”, otherwise the second tape is replaced by “no”.
Machines with oracles

children.name: B ≤ A
keywords: B ≤ A

children.name: Fact. If B ≤ A and A ∈ P, then B ∈ P
keywords: Fact. If B ≤ A and A ∈ P, then B ∈ P

children.name: Fact. For every problem B ∈ NP, B ≤ “NP halting problem”
keywords: Fact. For every problem B ∈ NP, B ≤ “NP halting problem”

children.name: Therefore, if the NP halting problem is in P, then P = NP.
keywords: Therefore, if the NP halting problem is in P, then P = NP.

children.name: Attention: this is not the usual notion of reduction for NP-completeness
keywords: Attention: this is not the usual notion of reduction for NP-completeness

children.name: Also makes sense for exponential time, or logarithmic space, etc.
keywords: Also makes sense for exponential time, or logarithmic space, etc.
Turing reductions

children.name: Karp reductions
Deterministic polynomial time Karp reduction
keywords: Deterministic polynomial time Karp reduction

children.name: Idea. Problem B can be solved by a deterministic polynomial time Turing machine, which is allowed to ask one oracle query to A, at the end of its computation, and respond with the oracle answer.
keywords: Idea. Problem B can be solved by a deterministic polynomial time Turing machine, which is allowed to ask one oracle query to A, at the end of its computation, and respond with the oracle answer.

children.name: Σ*
keywords: Σ*

children.name: we call this a polynomial time reduction
keywords: we call this a polynomial time reduction

children.name: If there is a Karp reduction, then there is a Turing reduction.
keywords: If there is a Karp reduction, then there is a Turing reduction.

children.name: The “NP halting problem” is complete already with respect to Karp reductions.
keywords: The “NP halting problem” is complete already with respect to Karp reductions.

children.name: Why?
keywords: Why?

children.name: Why Karp?
Karp reduction can distinguish problems that are interreducible with respect to Turing reductions.
keywords: Karp reduction can distinguish problems that are interreducible with respect to Turing reductions.

children.name: Complete problems
PSpace

children.name: NP complete
Definition. A language A is called NP-complete if: 1. it belongs to NP 2. every language L ∈ NP reduces to A
keywords: Definition. A language A is called NP-complete if: 1. it belongs to NP 2. every language L ∈ NP reduces to A

children.name: Karp deterministic LogSpace reduction
keywords: Karp deterministic LogSpace reduction

children.name: Logspace reductions
We mainly use (Karp) reductions computable in LogSpace
keywords: We mainly use (Karp) reductions computable in LogSpace
Logspace reductions

children.name: We do not know if there is a language which: – is NP-complete for polynomial time reductions – is not NP-complete for LogSpace reductions
keywords: We do not know if there is a language which: – is NP-complete for polynomial time reductions – is not NP-complete for LogSpace reductions

keywords: Example 1. The NP halting problem

children.name: Example 2. Satisfiability for Boolean formulas
keywords: Example 2. Satisfiability for Boolean formulas

children.name: Cook 1
Theorem. (Cook) The following problem is NP complete (for LogSpace reductions).
keywords: Theorem. (Cook) The following problem is NP complete (for LogSpace reductions).

children.name: Input. A Boolean formula φ, e.g. x ∨ (y ∧ ¬ x)
keywords: Input. A Boolean formula φ, e.g. x ∨ (y ∧ ¬ x)

children.name: Question. Is φ true for some valuation val : variables ⟶ {true, false}?
keywords: Question. Is φ true for some valuation val : variables ⟶ {true, false}?

children.name: Proof. The problem is clearly in NP: a nondeterministic machine can guess the satisfying valuation.
keywords: Proof. The problem is clearly in NP: a nondeterministic machine can guess the satisfying valuation.

children.name: Let us now prove NP-hardness, i.e. every other problem in NP reduces to SAT.
keywords: Let us now prove NP-hardness, i.e. every other problem in NP reduces to SAT.

children.name: Suppose that B ⊆ Σ* is in NP, as witnessed by a machine M and a polynomial p

children.name: Thm. (Ladner) If P ≠ NP, then there is a problem which is neither in P, nor NP-complete.

children.name: Ladner's Theorem
Consider some NP-complete problem A ⊆ Σ*, e.g. the NP halting problem.
keywords: Consider some NP-complete problem A ⊆ Σ*, e.g. the NP halting problem.

children.name: Let pad : Σ* ⟶ Γ* be an injective function such that:
keywords: Let pad : Σ* ⟶ Γ* be an injective function such that:

children.name: (a) the output size of pad grows faster than every polynomial (b) it can be inverted in polynomial time
keywords: (a) the output size of pad grows faster than every polynomial (b) it can be inverted in polynomial time

children.name: the inverse is a function of type Γ* ⟶ Σ* + {⊥}
keywords: the inverse is a function of type Γ* ⟶ Σ* + {⊥}

children.name: Consider the language pad(A) = {pad(w) : w ∈ A}
keywords: Consider the language pad(A) = {pad(w) : w ∈ A}

children.name: Assuming P ≠ NP and (a) and (b), then pad(A) is not NP-complete
keywords: Assuming P ≠ NP and (a) and (b), then pad(A) is not NP-complete

children.name: Assuming A ∉ P, we can choose pad so that (a) and (b) and pad(A) ∉ P
keywords: Assuming A ∉ P, we can choose pad so that (a) and (b) and pad(A) ∉ P
